( Character response) PLeasure can be so exhausting.It was possible that, in...[his] eyes, money represented some element in which he knew himself deficient: rather in the same way that [ another character] , when he wanted to criticize...said that he had too much money: no doubt in truth envying the possession of assets that were, in fact, not material ones.There are certain people who seem inextricably linked in life; so that meeting one acquaintance in the street means that a letter, without fail will arrive in a day or two from an associate involuntarily harnessed to him, or her, in time...It is as if the tempo altered gradually, so that too violent a change of sensation should not take place; in this case, that some of the atmosphere of school should be reconstructed, although only in a haphazard fashion, as if for an amateur performance, in order that I should not meet [him] in his new surroundings without a reminder of the circumstances in which we had first known one another.This was the last I should see of [him] for a long time. The path had suddenly forked. With regret, I accepted the inevitability of circumstance. Human relationships flourish and decay, quickly and silently, so that those concerned scarcely know how brittle, or how inflexible, the ties that bind them have become...A new epoch was opening: in a sense this night was the final remnant of life at school.The canvases...[t]hey made me think of long forgotten conflicts and compromises between the imagination and the will, reason and feeling, power and sensuality; together with many more specifically personal sensations, experienced in the past, of pleasure and pain....[N}othing establishes the timelessness of Time like those episodes of early experience seen, on reexamination at a later period, to have been crowded together with such unbelievable closeness in the course of a few years; yet equally giving the illusion of being so infinitely extended during the months when actually taking place....{I}f I considered him at all as a recurrent factor, I should have been prepared to admit that he might crop up again. I did not, however, as yet see him as one of those symbolic figures, of whom most people possess at least one example, if not more, round whom the past and the future have a way of assembling.I found myself wondering whether, so far from loving her, I did not actually hate her.{She} never touched strong drink, in spite of behavior that often suggested the contrary.Certain actions take place outside the normal course of things so unexpectedly that they seem to paralyse ordinary capacity for feeling surprise...It would, indeed, be hard to over-estimate the extent to which persons with similar tastes can often, in fact almost always, observe these responses in others: women: money: power: whatever it is they seek; while this awareness remains a mystery to those in whom such tendencies are less highly, or not at all, developed.On the contrary, inconsistency in his own line of thought worried him scarcely at all.Simple--like all great ideas.He was again showing recklessness in giving voice to these spasmodic outbursts of worldly knowledge....I reflected on the difficulty of believing in the existence of certain human beings...even in the face of unquestionable evidence--indications sometimes even wanting in the case of persons for some reason more substantial to the mind---that each had dreams and desires like other men...If a clue to that problem could be found, other mysteries of life might be revealed.I used to imagine life divided into separate compartments, consisting for example, of such dual abstractions as pleasure and pain, love and hate, friendship and enmity; and more material classifications like work and play: a profession or calling being, according to that concept--one that seemed, at least on the surface unequivocally assumed by persons...dissimilar from one another...something entirely different from 'spare time'. The illusion--as such a point of view was, in due course, to appear--was closely related to another belief: that existence fans out indefinitely into new areas of experience, and that almost every additional acquaintance offers some supplementary world with its own hazards and enchantments. As time goes on, of course, these supposedly different worlds, in fact, draw closer. if not to each other, then to some pattern common to all; so that, at last, diversity between them, if in truth existent, seems to be almost imperceptible except in a few crude and exterior ways: unthinkable as formerly appeared any single consummation of cause and effect. In other words, nearly all in the inhabitants of these outwardly disconnected empires turn out at last to be tenaciously inter-related; love and hate, friendship and enmity, too, becoming themselves much less clearly defined, more often than not showing signs of possessing characteristics that could claim, to say the least, not a little in common; while work and play merge indistinguishably into a complex tissue of pleasure and tedium.If certain individuals fall in love from motives of convenience, they can be contrasted with plenty of others in who passion seems principally to be aroused by the intensity of administrative difficulties in procuring its satisfaction.I felt that, if we could avoid seeing each other for long enough, any questions of sentiment...could be allowed quietly to subside, and take their place in those niches of memory especially reserved for abortive emotional entanglements of that particular kind.Perhaps intimacy of any sort, love or friendship, impedes all exactness of definition...In short, the persons we see most clearly are not necessarily those we know best.I was far from understanding that the capacity of men interested in power is not necessarily expressed in the brilliance of their conversation.A sense of maturity, or at least of endured experience, is conveyed, for some reason, in the smell of autumn.[She] is an excellent specimen of middle-class female education brought to its logical conclusions...She couldn't be more perfect even if she had done to the university. Her head is stuffed full of all the most pretentious nonsense you can think of, and she is incapable---but literally incapable---of thought. The upper class and lower classes can sometimes keep their daughters in order---the middle class, rarely, if ever.Funerals make one's mind drift in the direction of moral relaxation--though it's unaccountable to me the way intimate relations between the sexes are always spoken of, and written about, as if of necessity enjoyable or humorous. In practice they might much more truly be described as encompassing the whole range of human feeling from the height of bliss to the depths of misery....{H}interlands are frequently, even compulsively, crossed at one time or another by almost all who practice the arts, usually in the need to earn a living; but the arts themselves, so it appeared to me as I considered the matter, by their ultimately sensual essence, are, in the long run, inimical to those who pursue power for its own sake. Conversely, the artist who traffics in power does so, if not necessarily disastrously, at least at considerable risk.Nothing in life can ever be entirely divorced from myriad other incidents; and it is remarkable, though no doubt logical, that action, built up from innumerable causes, each in itself allusive and unnoticed more often than not, is almost always provided with an apparently ideal moment for its final expression. So true is this that what has gone before is often, to all intents and purposes, swallowed up by the aptness of the climax; opportunity appearing, at least on the surface, to be the sole cause of fulfillment. There is a strong disposition in youth, from which some individuals never escape, to suppose that everyone else is having a more enjoyable time than we are ourselves...At the same time there was an area of common ground where disparagement of other people brought them close together, if only on account of the ammunition with which each was able to provide the other: mutual aide that went far to explain a friendship long established.For reasons not always at the time explicable, there are specific occasions when events begin suddenly to take on a significance previously unsuspected; so that, before we really know where we are, life seems to have begun in earnest at last, and we ourselves, scarcely aware that any change has taken place, are careering uncontrollably down the slippery avenues of eternity.Dedicated, it might well be asked, to what? The questions would not be easy to answer. Dedicated, perhaps, to his own egotism; his determination to be--without adequate moral or intellectual equipment--absolutely different from everybody else.People can only be themselves...If they possessed the qualities you desire in them, they would be different people.Those interminable latter days of the dying year create an interval, as it were, of moral suspension: one form of life already passed away before another has had time to assert some new, endemic characteristic. Imminent change of direction is for some reason often foreshadowed by such colorless patches of time.I began to brood on the complexity of writing a novel about English life, a subject difficult enough to handle with authenticity even of a crudely naturalistic sort, even more to convey the inner truth of the things observed....{A}n inexorable law governs all human existence in that respect, ordaining that sooner or later everyone must appear before the world as he is. Many are not prepared to face tis sometimes distasteful principle. Indeed, the illusion that anyone can escape from the marks of his vocation is an aspect of romanticism common to every profession.I had not thought of her for ages, though some small residue of inner dissatisfaction, that survives all emotional expenditure come to nothing, now returned.But, in a sense, nothing in life is planned--or everything is--because in the dance every step is ultimately the corollary of the step before: the consequence of being the kind of person one chances to be. There is always a real and an imaginary person you are in love with; sometimes you love one best, sometimes the other. At that moment it was the real one I loved. I reflected, not for the first time, how mistaken it is to suppose there exists some "ordinary" world into which it is possible at will to wander. All human beings, driven as they are at different speeds by the same Furies, are at close range equally extraordinary.I wondered why he and his wife did not get on better. It was extraordinary that he seemed to please so many girls, and yet not her.Such a taste is hard to justify.Pictures, apart from their aesthetic interest, can achieve the mysterious fascination of those enigmatic scrawls on walls, the expression of Heaven knows what psychological urge on the part of the executant.Just as well he's passed away...In any case I always think an artist is rather an embarrassment to his own work.Emotional crises always promote the urgent need for executive action, so that the times when we most hope to be free from the practical administration of life are always those when the need to cope with a concrete world is more than ever necessary.But description of a woman's outward appearance can hardly do more than echo the terms of a fashion paper. Their nature can be caught only in a refractive beam, as with light passing through water: the rays of character focused through the person with whom they are intimately associated.Women can be immensely obtuse about all kinds of things...but where emotions are concerned their opinion is always worthy of consideration.I thought of love, which from the very beginning perpetually changes its shape: sometimes in the ascendant, sometimes in decline.

It's difficult to write about this series without mentioning Proust at some point, so I might as well get it out of the way now. It's probably not a coincidence I'm reading this series not long after finishing a certain doorstop of a translated French novel, for one thing they stack really nicely together and if you're browsing in a well-stocked bookstore they're shelved conveniently near each other thanks to the last names being very similar. It doesn't take long for the eye to wander from the shelf devouring Proust behemoths to the equally epic looking series of Powell novels and perhaps wondering, "Which one should I read?" And in case you're wondering if I'm overstating this slightly, at least two pull quotes from noted authors or critics on my edition of this volume distinctly compare it to Proust (implying that it's better, frankly, although Evelyn Waugh is kind of on record as not being that fond of Proust in the first place), so it's almost like they expect you to draw comparisons. Geez, as if the fact that both works are gigantic as all heck isn't enough.Honestly, it's really two different experiences, not completely dissimilar but akin to standing outside of an aquarium and watching the fish go by instead of being utterly dunked inside the tank to let the whole ocean envelope you. I'm early yet into Powell's epic but the almost suffocating thematic weight and laser-beam like focus on the internal crises of the narrator that distinguish Proust aren't quite on display here yet (let's remember that I'm only a quarter of the way through, it may be a bit of a slow burner). The concepts of Time and mortality and memory and how we're the sum of the intersection of all those forces are felt more strongly in the Frenchman's work and despite the narrator's weirdly obsessive quest to prove that every woman in Paris is a lesbian, you come away from that work feeling like you know what makes him tick, even if some of that understanding just wants to make you slap him. And that's going to be my last Proust/Powell comparison. At least in this review, I can't make any promises for the future.Still, the pleasures here are much more immediate and go down far easier, eschewing sprawlingly complex sentence structures for ones that human beings can actually reach the end of in their lifetimes, but maintaining a vocabulary level that would make your high school English teacher weep with joy that you got to use all the words she taught you. Powell has a smooth and easy style, along with a light touch that makes everything delightfully digestible and while some people label these as comic novels, it's not so much a comedic tone as delicately prodding, the narrator skipping over events with a refined and witty eye. There's very few lines that made me laugh out loud and there's nothing explicitly harrowing here but there are moments when you can see the start of things that could go to very dark places later.What is it about, though? Four lads that we first meet at school in the wake of World War One. While all the adults are still properly shellshocked around them for experiencing what they'll consider for a little while the worst mankind has to offer, our narrator Jenkins and his three friends (or two friends and one sort of persistent hanger-on) navigate their way not just through the post WWI/pre-WWII years of British high society but also the thorny paths of becoming adults, with all the expectations and dreams colliding in ways that don't always work out. And meeting girls. Many, many girls.A couple things make the structure interesting, at least for people who wonder how someone can write what is essentially a three thousand page novel that doesn't quite bog down under its own weight or disappear up its own rear. For one, Jenkins is clearly narrating the tale some years down the line, and often makes references to future events or that he won't see people for years at a time, which gives a sense of the scope of this affair. It's not clear that we're actually leading up to anything other than "My life is a series of lessons on how my friends refuse to make smart decisions) but it does helps reinforce the epic quality (even if it's more "hey, we're at another party" epic and not "ancient knights and warlords" epic), despite those events being decidedly mundane. In true Dostoevsky fashion, the boys can be divided into their basic human elements, for those who like charting the vaguely satirical nature of their progress through life. And the tone has that particular British melancholy that they might as well to bottle and sell in shops for pale, lonely boys who are true poets on the inside, with the narration leaping without warning into some lyrical insights, sometimes giving the impression that what is superimposed on the narrative are two overlapping concerns, a young man so in the moment that he can't ever imagine being old, and an old man desperately attempting to imagine what it was like to be young.But for the most part, the plot resides in a rambling and vaguely episodic series of events as Jenkins pilots his way through life somehow convinced that even though he's telling us the story we don't need to know anything about him except what he tells other people. In true epic novel fashion, a good chunk of events are spent at parties and sometimes the book seems to be a chronicle of the incidences where Jenkins runs into people he knows over the years, no matter how coincidental it seems to be after a while (London's a small town after all, wot?). There are points where you can't quite tell if he is stalking fellow former classmate Widmerpool (by far the novel's most finely sketched character) or vice versa, since they don't even seem to like each other that much. He plunges through his life like the slow trickle of an ice water leak, drifting every so often back into the orbits of his former schoolmates, like checking in with old friends to see how successful they've been, or time has already started to ravage them.It would make for a very even reading experience, like a smooth drink that barely leaves behind any hint of a burning sensation, if not for the huge cast of characters that Powell creates to populate his fictional world. Not only are there Jenkins' classmates but a quite varied assortment of characters, from old uncles to artists to Communists to old authors to women of dubious virtue, all of whom are delineated with a painter's eye and make the book come alive in a way that reading about the five hundredth high society party Jenkins attends and barely affects events can manage. Even the characters that only appear for brief stretches liven the book up, whether it's Jenkins' uncle popping in like some sitcom guest star, or the strange lady who may or may not have psychic powers. Powell's ability to cram these people in the novel and not have them fight each other for superiority, where they have space without sucking up all the oxygen, is a pretty remarkable feat and while I may have trouble remembering some of them come book twelve, it gives Powell an endless combination of scenarios to concoct, even if the basic setting is more or less the same (and despite some dips into a vaguely middle-class pool, we're hanging out in Gatsby territory here). The only character that comes close to stealing every scene he's in is Widmerpool, whose intense focus on himself to the exclusion of all else makes him like a model for Ricky Gervais' character on "The Office", unaware of how ridiculous he comes across but utterly serious in his aims. In fact, he probably wouldn't even care if he realized how he came across (there's a hilarious scene toward the end of the novel where he gives a completely inappropriate political speech and when someone has a stroke in the midst of it, seems more put out that he couldn't properly finish).It's those and other scenes (a Communist march where Jenkins witnesses an unexpected attendee is another standout) that surface throughout the novel that give us the feel of real life, the dry comedy that exists underneath the seriousness, or the desperation that sometimes underlies the comedy (you can almost see the horror in "any girl that moves is fair game" Templer's eyes as he tries not to contemplate what he'll be like in fifty years). It may be a real life where you seemingly run into the same twenty people over and over again but it's that's dance the title of the series refers to, where you can lose yourself in the rhythm and flow of it, until somebody trips and you suddenly look around, still caught in the dance but suddenly very aware of how much everything can change, especially when you're not looking.

description: A Question of Upbringing, A Buyer's Market, The Acceptance WorldAnthony Powell's brilliant twelve-novel sequence chronicles the lives of over three hundred characters, and is a unique evocation of life in twentieth-century England. It is unrivalled for its scope, its humour and the enormous pleasure it has given to generations. These first three novels in the sequence follow Nicholas Jenkins, Kenneth Widmerpool and others, as they negotiate the intellectual, cultural and social hurdles which stand between them and the 'Acceptance World'.
title:
A Dance to the Music of Time, Volume 1: Spring
      
          (A Dance to the Music of Time #1-3)
